turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Radar in World War II.
turn.1: What are the different types of radar?
turn.2: Other variants were the "SF", a set for lighter warships, the "SH" for large merchant vessels, and the "SE" and "SL", for other smaller ships.
turn.3: What are the similarities and differences between them?
turn.4: The Navy also adopted versions of the Army's "SCR-584" (without the "M-9" unit but with gyro-stabilizers) for shipboard search radars, the "SM" for fleet carriers and the "SP" for escort carriers.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: None of these were produced in large quantities, but were highly useful in operations.
turn.7: Did they have any other uses?
turn.8: The BTL developed the "SJ", an S-Band supplement for the "SD" meter-wave radar on submarines.
turn.10: The antenna for the "SJ" could sweep the horizon to about 6 miles with good accuracy.
turn.11: Did they improve upon this technology?
turn.12: Late in the war, the improved "SV" increased detection ranges to 30 miles.
